labels.analysis: The MCP Server is designed specifically to handle OpenAPI specification files, allowing users to split large OpenAPI files into smaller components or extract specific endpoints into new files. This functionality supports better management and integration of OpenAPI documents, making it easier for AI assistants and MCP clients to manipulate these specifications programmatically. The primary tools available indicate a focus on automated manipulation of OpenAPI files, which aligns with software development workflows and API integration tasks.
labels.reasoning: The primary label "API Integration" was chosen because the server facilitates manipulation and management of OpenAPI specifications, which are fundamental to API integration workflows. The secondary label "Development Tools" is relevant because it aids in software development by streamlining API specifications. No custom label is needed as predefined categories sufficiently describe the functionality.

server_info_crawled.name: OpenAPI Unbundle Server
server_info_crawled.author: @auto-browse/unbundle_openapi_mcp
server_info_crawled.overview: Split and extract parts of OpenAPI specification files programmatically. Enable AI assistants and MCP clients to manipulate OpenAPI specs by unbundling large files into smaller components or extracting specific endpoints into new files. Simplify OpenAPI management and integration workflows with automated tooling.

tools.name: split_openapi
tools.description: Deploy Server OpenAPI Unbundle Server Claim Server @auto-browse/unbundle_openapi_mcp Try in Playground split_openapi

server_info_crawled.python_sdk:
import mcp
from mcp.client.streamable_http import streamablehttp_client
import json
import base64

smithery_api_key = ""
url = f"https://server.smithery.ai/@auto-browse/unbundle_openapi_mcp/mcp?api_key={smithery_api_key}"

async def main():
    # Connect to the server using HTTP client
    async with streamablehttp_client(url) as (read_stream, write_stream, _):
        async with mcp.ClientSession(read_stream, write_stream) as session:
            # Initialize the connection
            await session.initialize()
            # List available tools
            tools_result = await session.list_tools()
            print(f"Available tools: {', '.join([t.name for t in tools_result.tools])}")

if __name__ == "__main__":
    import asyncio
    asyncio.run(main())
